#â€‹521 â€” September 3, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go 1.23's New unique Package â€” The packageâ€™s purpose is to make comparing values more efficient by using deduplication to point to unique, canonical copies, a concept called interning. Some knowledge is required, but Michael walks through everything you need to know, including a practicalÂ example.

Michael Knyszek (Go Team)

Tips for Building Bubble Tea Programs â€” Bubble Tea is a powerful Go framework for building terminal user interfaces (TUIs). Louis has spent a lot of time building PUG (a Terraform TUI) and shares the fruits of his experienceÂ here.

Louis Garman

ğŸ¥³ And, happily, Bubble Tea just celebrated reaching version 1.0! And was then quickly followed with v1.1 which adds focus and blur windowÂ events.

Go Beyond Limits with Golang, Rust, Docker &Â K8â€™s â€” Struggling with tech challenges? Ardan Labs offers unparalleled consulting in Go, Rust, Docker, and Kubernetes. Enhance your development speed, optimize your architecture, and manage tech debt. Propel your team to new heights with ourÂ expertise!

Ardan Labs Consulting sponsor

Slices in Go: Grow Big or Go Home â€” A deep dive into slices that focuses on how slices grow, something that can bite you right in the code when you donâ€™t understand it. For example, do you know when (and why) a slice ends up on the heap (orÂ not)?

Phuong Le (VictoriaMetrics)

IN BRIEF:

  • There's an active proposal to introduce a package that brings weakÂ pointers/references toÂ Go.

  • Go-HTMX, an approach building frontend UI components in Go, rather than JavaScript, has just reached version 1.0.

  • Matt Boyle has opened up a waitlist for Chris Shepherd's forthcoming Building Production-Ready Services with gRPC and Go course.

  • ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· GopherCon Korea 2024 is taking place this year in Hanam (near Seoul) onÂ OctoberÂ 12-13.

Dumb Ways to Die: Random Values in Pointers â€” Storing non-pointer values in unsafe.Pointer is.. a Bad Ideaâ„¢, but why? What happens? The journey and answer could help you better understand pointers and unsafe.

Phil Pearl

Mastering ISO 8583 Message Networking with Go â€” ISO 8583 is an interchange standard for card-based financial transactions (such as from a point-of-sale terminal orÂ ATM).

Pavel Gabriel

ğŸ“„ Building Terminal Applications in Go â€“ With Bubble Tea, Cobra, andÂ Viper. Harrison Cramer

ğŸ“„ Building Go Stack Traces from BPF â€“ Based on work being done by Grant to improve Datadogâ€™s GoÂ instrumentation. Grant Seltzer

ğŸ“„ Exploring Goja: A Go-Powered JavaScript Runtime JT Archie

ğŸ“º Shallow vs Deep Copying in Go Adib Hanna

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Tunalog: A No-Install Blogging System Built in Go â€” With Markdown, theming support, and Web-based editing, Tunalog provides all a simple blog framework needs. Itâ€™s been two years in the making, but its creator is finally happy with it, and judging by the screenshots itâ€™s pretty slick. Itâ€™s cross-platform and usesÂ SQLite.

Yami Odymel

wp2hugo: A WordPress to Hugo Blog Migrator â€” Hugo is a popular Go-powered static site generator and this tool makes it easy to convert WordPress-powered blogs over to it, including lots of edge cases WordPressâ€™s REST API doesnâ€™t helpÂ with.

Ashish Bhatia

Kafka-Compatible Data Streaming That Reduces Costs and Ops Burden â€” Zero ops auto-scaling. Perfect provisioning. 10x cheaper than Kafka. Try WarpStream for free and get $400 inÂ credits.

WarpStream sponsor

GoForge: A CLI Tool to Streamline Go Project Initialization â€” Rather than manually creating files and directories to set up a projectâ€™s structure, GoForge provides a one-lineÂ alternative.

Moutaz Chaara

BadgerDB 4.3: A Fast, Embeddable Key-Balue DB in Go â€” Designed as a performant alternative to non-Go-based key-value stores like RocksDB. Docs.

Dgraph

hyrumtoken: A Package to Encrypt Pagination Tokens â€” For when you donâ€™t want API clients to access unintended 'features' of your pagination related parameters, say.

SSOReady

  • FrankenPHP 1.2.5 â€“ Modern Go-powered PHP appÂ server. There's also a new guide explaining how to get the most performance fromÂ it.

  • FerretDB 1.24 â€“ A database that acts like MongoDB but uses Postgres forÂ storage.

  • gRPC-Go 1.66 â€“ Go implementation of gRPC for HTTP/2 basedÂ RPC.

  • Viddy 1.1 â€“ A modern Go-powered watchÂ alternative.

  • OpenFGA 1.6 â€“ Google Zanzibar-inspired authorizationÂ engine.

  • go-enry 2.8.9 â€“ Programming language detectionÂ CLI/library.

  • pdfcpu 0.8.1 â€“ Go PDFÂ processor.

ğŸ And one for fun..

Âµ micro: A Go-Powered Terminal-Based Text Editor â€” Aiming to be â€œsomewhat of a successor to the nano editorâ€, Micro has been under development for several years and is a mature and good example of building a text editor in Go. GitHubÂ repo.

Zachary Yedidia et al.

item.title: ã€The GopherCon UK experienceã€‘è‹±å›½ GopherCon ä½“éªŒ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹519 â€” August 20, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–ï¸ If you missed last week's issue, don't worry - you didn't. I took a week off for a summer break, but now we're back ;-) Thanks to everyone who sent in links for us to checkÂ out.
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Go 1.23 Released â€” Weâ€™ve been hearing about (and linking to) 1.23 for weeks in its various pre-release guises, but now it's here. You could call 1.23 a 'major minor' release, as it's mostly a gentle step forward but with some new features, like for range iteration and tooling additions (including the now opt-in telemetry system). Head to the official release notes for all theÂ details.

The Go Team

ğŸ’¡ For a more practical look at language improvements, don't forget Anton Zhiyanov's fantastic interactive release notes andÂ examples.

Structs are Copied on Assignment (and Other Things About Go I'd Missed) â€” This gotcha likely catches many new-to-intermediate gophers, along with the other issues Julia also mentions. By the way, these are based on a few of the 100 Go Mistakes and How to Avoid Them site andÂ book.

Julia Evans

A Complete Introduction to Containers â€” Join Brian Holt for this extensive video course covering the now industry standard approach for developing and deploying apps. You'll learn about core container technology, Docker Images, multi-container projects, and muchÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

â–¶Â Â 12 Talks from GopherCon UK 2024 â€” GopherCon UK took place just a few days ago, but you can already enjoy a variety of talks including Matt Boyle on debugging Go apps, JesuÌs Espino digging into Goâ€™s runtime, Beth Anderson on AI, and Googleâ€™s Michael Pratt look at profile guidedÂ optimization. We'll feature more talks in future issues as we watch them, as there's a lot of gold inÂ here.

GopherCon UK

ğŸ’¡ If you want to get more of a feel for what the event was like, Jamie Tanna did a write up of the GopherCon UK 2024 experience.

HTTP/1.0 From Scratch â€” We recently featured Kevinâ€™s HTTP/0.9 From Scratch, a first step into reimplementing the basics of HTTP, step by step, in Go. Now we get to fast forward five years to 1996 and HTTP/1.0 which introduced things like the POST action, status codes, and contentÂ negotiation.

Kevin McDonald

'An Unordered List of Things I Miss in Go' â€” A solid list with some doable and not-so-doable items. On the doable side, there are ordered maps and default arguments. On the not-so-doable, null/nilability is a long-time contentious subject that likely would break backwardÂ compatibility.

kokada

Go Maps Explained: How Key-Value Pairs Are Actually Stored â€” A comprehensive, illustrated tutorial to how things are represented under theÂ hood.

Phuong Le

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

go-vcr 4.0: Record and Replay Your HTTP Interactions â€” Record and replay API interactions for faster, deterministic testing of potentially flaky endpoints â€“ hereâ€™s the v4.0 changelog. (If youâ€™ve used Ruby, you might recognize its inspiration: the popular VCRÂ library.)

Marin Atanasov Nikolov

GoNB: A Go Notebook Kernel for Jupyter â€” Notebooks make it easy to do literate programming where you see results immediately like a REPL but with persistence and control over the source code. Common in Python, GoNB brings Go into the picture too. The latest release adds Jupytext support.

Jan Pfeifer

FusionAuth. Auth Built for Devs, by Devs â€” Choose self-hosting or cloud, scale from 10 to 10 million users, and enjoy unlimited IDPs. Trusted by industry leaders with 10M+Â downloads.

FusionAuth sponsor

Pie 2.9: A Utility Library for Dealing with Slices â€” Ways to work with slices with a focus on type safety, performance and immutability. Now with a a new UniqueStable operation.

Elliot Chance

Lo: A Lodash-Style Library for Go 1.18+ â€” Inspired by JavaScriptâ€™s Lodash and brings similar utility methods for working with slices, maps, andÂ more.

Samuel Berthe

kubetrim: Trim Your KUBECONFIG Automatically â€” Takes your kubeconfig and trims out all the old / unused clusters andÂ contexts.

Alex Ellis

  • Bubble Tea 0.27 â€“ The powerful, popular TUI framework adds support for programmatically suspending and resumingÂ programs.

  • GoLand 2024.2 â€“ The latest release of JetBrains' popular commercial GoÂ IDE.

  • Pion TURN 4.0 â€“ Toolkit for building TURN clients andÂ servers.

  • GoReleaser 2.2 â€“ Build/release binaries for multipleÂ platforms.

  • wazero 1.8 â€“ Zero dependency WebAssembly runtime forÂ Go.

  • NATS.go 1.37 â€“ Go client for the NATS messagingÂ system.

  • gofumpt 0.7 â€“ A stricter gofmt.

#â€‹518 â€” August 6, 2024

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–ï¸ Hi! We're taking next week off for a brief summer break. We'll be back with our next issue on August 20. Also, if possible, can you click an item or two? We're going to be doing some 'list cleaning' soon and it's helpful to know if you're still keen to receive the newsletterÂ â€“ thanks!Â :-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Russ Cox Steps Down as Tech Lead of Go â€” Russ has been instrumental in many of Goâ€™s developments having led the project for 12 years, but itâ€™s time for a change with Austin Clements taking his position. But Russ isnâ€™t leaving the Go world. Indeed, he's already deep into a new project (seeÂ next)..

Russ Cox

Oscar: An Open-Source Contributor Agent Architecture â€” As Russ steps away as Go tech lead, heâ€™s stepping into more work on Oscar, an AI agent system to help maintain open-source projects. The first bot, Gaby, is already up and running on Goâ€™s issue tracker, with more toÂ come.

Russ Cox

Go! Unlock Your Tech Potential with Ardan Labs Consulting â€” Struggling with skill gaps, development speed or complex tech challenges? Ardan Labs specializes in Go, Rust, Docker and K8s to accelerate your software development, optimize architecture, and manage tech debt. Let us supercharge yourÂ team!

Ardan Labs Consulting sponsor

What's the Best Static Analysis Tool for Go? â€” Static analysis can be a valuable part of an appâ€™s quality toolchain, run by both developers and pipelines. But there are many options, official and otherwise, so which to choose? The answer is (kinda) all ofÂ themâ€¦?

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

A 10 Week Go Backend Engineer Onboarding Plan â€” Stream has published the onboarding program they use for Go developers, which covers the basics of Go, databases, HTTP, and more. This is a great idea and sets expectations if youâ€™re looking forÂ work.

Stream

Did You Know About Instruments? â€” Instruments is a macOS app that allows you to create various traces and profiles of running applications. It offers quite the toolset, as indicated by Thorstenâ€™s palpableÂ enthusiasm.

Thorsten Ball

Implementing HTTP/0.9 from Scratch â€” The first instalment of a â€œHTTP from Scratchâ€ series digging into the history of the protocol underpinning theÂ Web.

Kevin McDonald

ğŸ“º 5 Levels of Go Error Handling RageCageCodes

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

approf: A Native macOS App for pprof â€” An app experience for viewing the results from pprof profiling that includes drag/drop, reordering, light/dark mode, and savedÂ sessions.

Moderato

Glamour: Stylesheet-based Markdown Rendering for Your CLIÂ Apps â€” Glamour lets you render simple Markdown from your app but then have styles applied to it so that it looks more colorful and elegant once it lands in theÂ terminal. Another great piece of work from the folks at Charm.

Charm

Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease â€“ from your first user to yourÂ billionth.

Render sponsor

mimetype: Library for Detecting MIME Types and Extensions â€” Supporting 173 different types, you pass in binary data, a data stream or filename and, hopefully, find out what type of data youâ€™re workingÂ with.

Gabriel Vasile

go-sqlbuilder: A Flexible SQL String Builder Library â€” Originally focused on MySQL and Postgres, it now supports SQL Server, SQLite, CQL, and more, too. Lets you use structs as a â€˜light weight ORMâ€™, and now also supports Common Table Expression andÂ ILIKE.

Huan Du

Minimock: A Tool to Generate Mocks from Interface Declarations â€” Generates statically typed mocks and helpers, is fully integrated with the testing package, and supportsÂ generics.

Juno Inc.

  • River 0.11 â€“ Fast and reliable Postgres-powered background jobs forÂ Go.

  • env 11.2 â€“ Zero dependency way to parse env variables intoÂ structs.

  • Dgraph 24.0 - Native GraphQL database with a graphÂ backend.

  • ğŸ‡¯ğŸ‡µ Kagome 2.10 â€“ Japanese morphologicalÂ analyzer.

  • Resty 2.14 â€“ Simple HTTP and REST clientÂ library.

  • webdav 5.1 â€“ Standalone WebDAVÂ server.

  • GoBGP 3.29 â€“ BGP implementation inÂ Go.

As mentioned earlier, we're taking a week off and will be back on August 20.

If you didn't find anything to click in this issue, how about enjoying â–¶ï¸Â thisÂ particularly high quality 1950s-themed attempt at the classic Steamed Hams gag from The Simpsons? ğŸ˜„
